description.text:
There isn't anything that runes more in this warm summer than a hand-held fan!
This things were used a long time ago, in ancient Greece and now we can continue using them... but 3D printed!
You can take it to the beach or to the swimmingpool and cause envy. Feel free to combine colors as you like; different printing colors, different papers, fabric...
You can also print it bigger and pay someone to fan you!
*Edit: I also created a fan holder because after some use the fan kind of spreads.

Follow the instructions for better results:

  1. Print Fan cover x2, fan sheets x14.
  2. Introduce a 1.75 mm PLA filament or other filament type trough all the pieces' holes.
  3. Cut each side of the filament leaving 2mm each side then heat both ends. Just before it starts to melt push it with a flat surface. That will turn the filament thicker and will prevent the pieces from scaping.
  4. From here, grab a DIN A3 paper sheet and follow the pictures. Be patient and enjoy the results!

You can just glue the pices on a paper, make it foldable, use fabric... Feel free to invent!

title: PLASTI-EAR: iPad Sound Horn for Targus iPad covers **UPDATED**

description.text:
UPDATED DESIGN!
The iPad has one speaker, and it is located on the back of the device. If you use a cover, like I do, there is a hole cut out of the back side of the cover for the speaker. However, when I stand the iPad up to watch a favorite TV show on Amazon, such as "The Big Bang Theory", the sound is muffled because it is being directed to the back of the iPad. What I eventually end up doing is using my hand to form a "cup" shape to redirect the sound to the front of the device. That works fine, but I would prefer if the the sound was directed towards me automatically so I would not have to use my hand to hear the sound better.
The Plasti-Ear for Targus iPad covers

Update: I have extended the curved piece that slips under the Targus cover. Now it holds on extremely well, and will not fly off as easily as it did in the first version. My latest thing is the the iPad Plasti-Ear, which is a sound horn for the Targus iPad cover. It is easy to print, and takes less less than 20 minutes on .27mm layer height (prints great at .2mm as well) and with acceleration settings in place on a Replicator 1 or 2/2x. Your mileage may vary. It is also easy to apply to your cover: Easy Instructions:

• Print the thing.
  • See picture 2 above. Find the corner with the speaker cut out. Push that corner out of the cover. Put the thin edge of the bottom section of the plati-ear into the cover's speaker cut out. Push it down a little (not too much, don't break it!) so that the thin edge is under the cover (this part has been extended, and new STL and SKP files have been uploaded) - see picture 3.
  • There is a lip that goes over the top edge of the Targus cover. Gently push the lip over the top edge of the cover, and then gently push the iPad back into the corner of the Targus cover. See image 3 for example.
  • Done! Picture 1 shows what it looks like when secured to the cover.
    • There are other ways to get it on, but once it is done correctly, you can shake the iPad and the Plasti-Ear will not come off. Of course, if you hit it, it will fly off, so watch it. (note: updated design makes it more difficult to knock the sound horn off). That's it! The STL and SKP files are there for proper manipulation and sharing. Ideas:

• Customize it! Add a some text to the inside of the Plasti-Ear to let everyone know you use 3D printin' to help you hear stuff.
  • You could also try making it is two colors if you have a dual head printer. I have one, but I have not make a two color version yet.
  • Print several off at once, and give them out as gifts to your family, friends, and clients! If you are doing this for a client, make sure to DEFINITELY add your contact info to the inside of the Plasti-Ear.

An iPhone 4/4S cover with knuckle and hearts. This product is to be used only as a handle and protective accessory for iPhone.
UPGRADE
I've uploaded a simplified version of the cover that was optimized for FDM printers and splitted in two parts. Good printing !!!

comments.text: If you extend the rings down to the build platform we won't have to use and cut off support material, leaving an ugly surface.  I printed at .25mm layer height and unfortunately the text didn't come out on the side.  Looks like braille.  The hearts did come out though.  The inner top rim that would hold the phone in didn't adhere well perhaps because it wasn't sloped? It peeled off like a single noodle. Otherwise it worked out pretty well.  I printed it for a buddy since I don't have an iPhone.
comments.author: lowlight

comments.text: This model was made for SLS printer and therefore has too small parts for FDM printers. I did several tests to print an usable iphone cover but FDM printers haven't the necessary precision to make a robust snap with 1mm walls. Anyway i' ll upload a simplified model for FDM printers soon. If the top rim don't adhere to phone try to scale down a bit (0,8-1,6 %) all the cover and check if your printer bed is levelled http://www.thingiverse.com/make:39168http://www.thingiverse.com/mak...
comments.author: lowlight

comments.text: Thanks for making the changes.  Not sure if/when I'll get to do a reprint.  I didn't exactly explain the top rim problem clearly enough though.  The slight overhang at the top which is meant to hold the phone in, had the inner loop or two not adhere and so I pulled them off.  There's a good chance it has to do with my calibration being way off.  The printer did suffer a head crash recently and they bed isn't level.  Today I gave the print to my buddy and it was a bit too tight for him to snap onto the phone without fear of breaking the case even with some of the top rim missing.
comments.author: alan89

comments.text: Lol. I've also changed the top rim and now should snap better. If cover is too tight you've to scale up a bit beacause ABS have a higher shrinkage then PLA. To print correctly the top rim you can try to set fan on that layer.

title: Sculpture of my wife and dog

description.text:
This is a test to see how easy it is to do a laser scan, and print to 3d.  
Worked ok for me in ABS, with a 15% fill, and raft. base is still a little rough...  
Let me know if it works for you.  
Updated file to fix some holes in the mesh that messed up some printers. Also oriented it properly for printing

Made using the nextengine 3d laser scanner and scanstudio HD.  
I had to use a raft to ensure it didn't fall over during the print. I also used supports for the arm.

comments.text: Falken76 - great feedback, thank you! I've been using the demo version Geomagic to try and simplify the models (this one scanned it at over 700 megs... ), but they are still huge, and I wasn't looking forward to the geomagic pricepoint. I'll check out topogun, looks perfect.
comments.author: alexzogh

comments.text: I have this scanner, You can certainly use it to scan and print in 3d.  If you have experience using 3d programs, the mesh is HUGE and not very managable if you need to do editing.  But there are programs out there like Topogun that let you use the scanned image as a reference mesh and you can create a low poly version with nearly the same detail, then load THAT into your 3d program and your model is able to be easily edited, rigged and animated.
comments.author: falken76

comments.text: Nice!

A video explaining the multitool:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dZSr72up1JQ

This is a multi-tool key chain I designed to be used while playing golf... It is part of a golf collection I've been designing. Below are the accompanying ball markers that go with this multi-tool...

This multi-tool will fit on/in any key chain, pocket, or golf bag. It will hold your ball marker, fix your divots, and open your beers.... What more can you ask for?

I designed a few dual or single extruded ball markers to go with this multi-tool... I plan on designing a few more (I'll take requests) but this is what I have right now.

Here is the Royal-TEE, golf tee I designed to go with the set...
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943623

The instructions are simple...

This is a single Extrusion print...

If you want the bottle opener to work, I suggest these settings.

Type - ABS/Nylon
Resolution - 0.2mm
Shells - 4-5
Infill - 100%

If you're not too worried about the bottle opener working, you can print in 2 shells at low infill... Everything else will work...

title: Rostock Max Magnetic Effector and Arm Plate Connectors

description.text: This is a magnet effector and the arm plate connectors for a Rostock Max printer.   It includes spots to mount (3) 25mm part fans and some LED strip lights.

Parts Needed (12) Â 1/2" Chrome Steel Ball Bearings (6) Magnetic arms Steps to assemble
  • All parts are printed with 100% infill and 4 shells (or loops). You should not use PLA for the effector. PLA doesn't stand up to the heat from the bed and will become too flexible when in use. ABS can be used. To make sure you are satisfied with the results, you may want to first try supergluing one of the balls to a single arm connector before printing the rest.
  • Print the effector first. Make sure it prints perfectly flat and there is no warping or curling of the edges. Near the end, it'll be printing the cups that hole the chrome balls. Some defects in the cups are ok as long as they can be removed and the balls are stable and don't wiggle when attempting to move them back and forth before gluing them. Make sure those print cleanly and without any overheating melty-ness. Consider turning on a fan when it is printing the cups.
  • Sand one spot on each of the 6 of the chrome balls to rough it up a bit so the glue will stick to it. Put a drop of glue into each of the effector ball cups and place the sanded spot of each chrome ball in the cup. If you get extra glue on the ball, that's ok. It can be carefully removed later with Acetone after it has dried. Lightly but securely clamp the ball down into the cup. If you don't have any clamps, inverting a second effector and placing it on top makes a good surface to put some weight on the balls while the glue is drying. Try resisting the temptation to play with it for a while.
  • Print one of the arm plate connectors next. Again, you want to get a very clean print since this will become part of your printer. You may need to tweak settings and try different materials until you get good results. PLA or ABS can be used for the arm plate connectors and I got the best results printing the arm connectors in PLA.
  • Print the other two arm plate connectors and glue the chrome balls to them.
  • Add the leveling screws from your old plate connectors to the new ones.
  • The arm plate connectors attach in the same spot as the old ones except they use the outer-most holes on each side.
  • Wire up the fans, LEDs and the hot end on the effector (I'll write up some more instructions on this in the future but you should be able to see most of what is involved by looking at the photographs of the finished effector.
  • Attach the effector to your printer with your magnetic arms.

comments.text: Whats your final verdict on magnetic ball joints? Do they have more freedom of movement? and do they stay stable in the sockets at all times?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: It is great when you are using it along with electrical connectors that let you easily take the head off to work on it or swap it out. I wouldn't say it has more freedom of movement but it does seem to be more accurate with less slop in the movement. It has popped out a couple times but that has been an indication of some other problem and in some cases it was better that it popped out like when it was driving the head into the print bed.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: why the fans? what is their purpose? isn't counterproductive to lower the temperature when printing with abs? aren't those fans are exact tehnological opposite of the heated bed and foremost the enclosed heated chamber? please reply
comments.author: azent

comments.text: I'm still figuring out all this stuff out and still have trouble with abs. I think it can help if you are trying to print something solid in abs or a small part where the heat can build up. Also, the fans aren't probably something you'd have on all the time. Just for certain parts or maybe when a part is reaching the final layers.
comments.author: azent

comments.text:
I would think those fans are for when printing PLA, it tends to like to be cooled as soon as possible.
Speaking of the fan holes is there any way to get a version without those in place? I know nothing of Scad so I'm not sure how to eliminate those. Thanks.
comments.author: azent

comments.text: To me, it would look too strange to remove the fan holes without moving things around in the design to reclaim the space. I'd end up thinkering with it for a few hours. You could just use it without putting any fans in those spots.

author: smokeandlights

description.text:
Where I work, we have a lot of spools laying around. To keep them from unspooling, we usually just thread the filament through one of the holes in the side of the spool. This works but it makes it difficult to stack spools on top of each other. I wanted a way to add a filament clip with a low profile that didn't interfere with normal unspooling while printing and didn't protrude past the side of the spool.

This part was designed to work specifically with the 3Dom USA Eco-Spools, but will work on pretty much any spool with a 3mm or larger hole near the rim.

The same part works with both 3mm and 1.75mm filament.

Requires an M3 screw (length dependent on thickness of spool).

Print the part in PLA with at least 3 shells (essentially 100% infill).

Thread the hole with an M3 tap or by slowly and repeatedly inserting and removing an M3 screw.

To install on a 3Dom USA Eco-Spool, use an M3 x 6mm button head screw with a single washer (to get the correct spacing) from the outside of the spool and install the clip facing away from the spool like in the pictures above.

For any other spool, use an M3 screw of the required length to catch a few layers of thread without sticking into the clip as this will interfere with the 1.75mm slot.

comments.text:
I would recommend making the sides rounded, as the filament may get stuck on the clip as the spool turns while printing.
I made a similar snap-in design, but had multiple scenarios where the filament jammed during print.

description.text: Other dice set weren't slicing properly for me so I created my own.
All dice print properly for me. The numbers on the d4 are somewhat small, I might fix that later. I printed the d10, d12, and d20 with some support.

comments.text: The D12 should not have the "8" at the bottom.  The dots in the "8" are difficult to adhere.
comments.author: JohnBPrice

comments.text: The D8 has a design flaw on the 6.
comments.author: Stoutlimb

comments.text:
I'm curious...
The d10 pictured above: what's up with the weird design? This d10 has each number contained on two faces. I have never seen that configuration before...
Has anyone seen this configuration before?
comments.author: skooler1

comments.text: The dice numbers are not correctly set. The opposite sides of a die must equal one more then the total number of faces. (i.e., the opposite faces of a d6 will always equal 7).Just from this, I can tell you that the dice will not be considered fair. The creater or modifier of dice models should take time to copy the correct number locations before printing. After that, setting the prints to solid may help balance issues
comments.author: njguman

comments.text: You are mostly correct. The one exception to this is the d10 - where opposite sides equal 9. This is because the d10 is technically numbered 0-9 and getting 11 from opposite sides is not possible for all opposing sides.
comments.author: njguman

comments.text: Any suggestions on how to print a pyramid without having the tip come out melted? I've printed two different models with the same melty result and am now considering altering the gcode to reduce the heat as the print nears completion. Currently printing on Type A Machine @ 220c with 1.75mm pla and .35mm extruder.
comments.author: imjohsep

comments.text: A bit late, but a sacrificial tower, or printing 2 of them at a time, will prevent this as well. Move the print head away from the tip while printing.
comments.author: imjohsep

comments.text: I had the best luck with printing 2 or 3 at a time. If you space them farther apart from each other then they have time to cool between layers.
comments.author: imjohsep

comments.text: Thanks, I'll give that a shot and update the results for this print.
comments.author: Tha177c

comments.text: Also in slicing software like Cura, there is an advanced setting that sets the minimal amount of time for an area to cool...Sorry, can’t remeber the name, but it is clear if you read the tooltips.
comments.author: imjohsep

comments.text: Have you test-rolled these to see if they are "fair" dice?  I've been mulling over what infill might be most appropriate for slicing these to keep them as fair as possible.
comments.author: jimdeane

comments.text: I did some test rolls and didn't find anything obvious. However, due to the nature of the printing process I suspect that infills closer to 100% will be the most fair.
comments.author: jimdeane

comments.text: I did a 40% infill on a 6 sided die and rolled to determine fairness. Even though I don't own a dice roller and my sample size was only 50 rolls, my chi squared results showed fairness in the die. Although, anecdotally I believe the bottom layer has a slightly higher chance of not being rolled. In my case that was the 4's side. If I get the print correct I will share the results.
comments.author: Tha177c

Guard for GPS Tracker RFv16

A well functional e-drum trigger pad. It's still work in progress but I'm very happy with the results so far. I'm going to build a whole e-drum set around this, including a kick-trigger and cymbals. You can watch the progress on thingiverse and for most recent changes look on my git repository:
https://github.com/Piesi/pE-Drums.git You are of course also well welcome to contribute! Non printed parts:
-Threaded rod (6mm,130mm)
-4 M6 75mm bolts
-6 M6 25mm bolts
-1 M6 50mm bolt
-M6 nuts
-Sensor piezo (like this one http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Electronic_component_piezo.jpg)
-8" meshhead
-a jack socket.
-sponge or felt (between the sensor and the mesh, hope to find
a printable solution soon) The printed parts of my version weight about 375g.

Print every part just one time, except the baseC and rim files. BaseC has to be printed 2, the rim 4 times. The biggest part, the shell, has a diameter of 180mm.
I have printed them with a 0.8mm nozzle, as for my experience this is the best choice for strong parts and fast results. Other print settings were 0.25mm layer height and 30% infill. Cut the threaded rod in pieces:
4 230mm
2 190mm The assembly can be figured out by the pictures, I hope. If you have problems, just ask:)

title: Narrative Clip Case with Adjustable Camera Cover

description.text: I liked sk8kim's narrative case, but noticed there were a few flaws such as no spaces for the charger or indicator light, and with the front of the clip covered the touch feature was a little tricky to activate. So I brought it into TinkerCAD and added those in, and also made a separate piece that can cover the camera at any time. Now all the functions of the narrative clip can be used without taking the case off.

I included the files together and separate incase people want to print in dual colors like I did. I printed the case at a .2 layer height, 50% infill, and supports. I printed the cover at .2 and 90% fill, but 50% is probably ok. After printing, it may require some sanding/filing to get the cover to fit.

When you are in an awkward position trying to attach a nut to a bolt, a finger wrench may be just what you need. Tight corners especially, and anywhere that requires reaching into the unknown: dropping a spanner down the back of a radiator is all too easy, dropping your finger is not.

I recently discovered this great little gadget on a DIY blog but unfortunately the company that originally supplied it is no longer making the product (why not??) and i can't find anywhere to purchase existing stock.

I had to have one, so I modelled and 3D printed this little beauty and it works a treat!

Easy to use:
There is a gap all down the back side, thereby allowing one size to fit a wide range of fingers. Slip a nut or bolt into the wrench as shown in the two images. Finger pressure keeps the nut or bolt in place. The tapered slot inside the wrench prevents the nut or bolt from turning.

Suitable for 1/2inch nut/bolt and smaller.

Print PLA (http://www.faberdashery.co.uk/products-page/print-materials/mellow-yellow/) or ABS 0.2mm 100% infill for strength.

UPDATE: 110915
I've evolved the design to a 'Pro' version.
A sleeker design and more ergonomic on the finger
FingerWrench_Pro.stl

Thanks to inspiration from MD80: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:997777

UPDATE: 190116
From a suggestion by bitschieber http://www.thingiverse.com/bitschieber/about
A version with more finger tip control to use with smaller fasteners

DISCLAIMER:
Please do not use this item with an impact wrench or any air powered tools - you may well destroy the Finger Wrench and more importantly, your finger!!

Enjoy!

title: Robotic platform for multiple configuration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi Maker ! With the desire to create a robot thanks to electronic solutions like Arduino and Raspberry pi I needed a solution to test the code . The commercial solutions do not appear to me suitable to my needs I have decided to design my own . So this platform has emerged. I share with you , if you encounter the same problem may be that it will be able to help you.

This is for easily and quickly mounting a robot with 2, 4 or 6 wheel drive or why not legs.
It measures 35 cm long and 25 cm wide and 6 cm high.
There is enough space to contain a Arduino Mega board with a motor shield .
There are :
A large door for easy access the interior .
Holes for fastening standard servo and stepper motor (nema 12 up to 17) on top and bottom to move sensor , arms, camera or what you want .
Slots for mounting sensors on the top and bottom to avoid obstacle.
Holes for fastening DC motor and stepper motor (nema12 up to 17)
on the sides .
09/20/2015 Adding mounting holes for lcd 16x02 and nuts cage for door .
The plan is intended for materials 3 mm thick .

Here is a video that shows some possible configuration.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4M6JiZvHn2w

Here are 3D printed parts for sensors:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1233546
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:938918

This proto was made at NYBI http://nybi.cc/

If you make it, thank you to let me know your opinion.

Doesn't Matter

title: QuadRevo Rage Series Adjustable Camera Plate

description.text:
This is an adjustable camera plate for the QuadRevo Micro uFR1 / Rage 180 / Rage 210 and the HS1177 Camera.

Three versions available, one offset so that it moves the whole camera forward which allows you to get more of an aggressive angle and gives you more room for the plugs. There is also a TPU Version that has slightly different dimensions for a tighter fit with TPU filament. This is the version I use on mine.

Alternatively you can just rotate the whole thing so that the angled part is facing forward which will get you the most distance forward and you can have a really aggressive camera angle.

Frame: QuadRevo Micro uFR1
Camera: HS 1177 DC5V-22V Plastic Case mini 600tvl Sony Super HAD CCD FPV Camera

Offset Plate: Printed with support due to the fact it's offset.

Regular one: No support worked fine.

I love my Nintendo DS LITE like everyone else. Also like everyone else I have picked up my system while in hibernation and as your hand curls around the outside of the DS LITE case you feel that dreaded click. That click that makes you wonder, "When was the last time I saved my game?", or "That boss was so hard, I hope I remembered to save!". Well worry no more, I have you covered, literally. The Game Saver is a cover that uses the pre-existing holes and charge port on the back of the system to attach itself covering the game cartridge. Simply print, and insert. It's that easy!

title: Seig Mini Mill X2 Intermediate gear

description.text:
I broke this gear while making the belt drive conversion to replace it. I didn't want to buy one just to have it become obsolete when I finish the mod so I printed one.
I was able to do some milling with the PLA gear, but eventually it melted and the teeth rounded over. then the key melted into the gear and it was dome.
Milling in short increments should be OK whit this, but it is a stop gap.
Print nearly solid.

comments.text: PLA makes crisp teeth, but melts if it gets too hot.
comments.author: erniepike

comments.text: If anybody makes this out of anything other than PLA, please post results?
comments.author: erniepike

comments.text: ABS lasted about an hour, failure mode was chewing through a few of the teeth. Printed with no-name ABS at 100% infill. Culprit might be user overdriving machine. Will try nylon tonight. That being said - thank you! this was a good stopgap solution to get a project done.
comments.author: erniepike

comments.text: Thanks, I had similar result with PLA but it was enough to Finnish the belt drive so I've had no reason /  opportunity for further testing.
comments.author: hahnpv

comments.text: hey thanks a lot for designing and posting this.  worked like a charm for my X2.  was right in the middle of a little job and broke the gear shifting from low to high while spindle spinning.  forgot that it needed to be done static.  was about to order a new gear for about $15 and decided to do a quick 3D printed part search and found this.  I used Taluman Nylon 645 which is stronger than PLA.  hoping it holds up.  printed at 80% infill and 0.3 resolution.  assembled and working again but have not milled anything yet.  thanks again
comments.author: phlynch

comments.text: Thanks, Nylon should be better. PLA was strong enough but melted. let me know if it holds up?

remixed_from.author: WestMD
remixed_from.title: 3D Printer Power Supply Cover (for LED PSU) Safety First!

description.text:
This is an upgrade for ToyREP 3D Printer, that will allow you to attach LED power supply under the Y axis, so it is a solid part of the printer.

Cover is now available for two sizes. Use ToyREP-PSU1 for 111x78x36mm or ToyREP-PSU2 for 129x99x38mm. The instructions are the same for both.

It have a main power switch and covering all the dangerous connections to make the printer safer. As was already mentioned in the printer description, 40W 12V should be just enough for hotend and movement. For 100x100mm heat bed you will need approximately another 40W. That makes total 80W. I am currently using 75W PSU. It is sufficient for printing when heaters are already heated up and consuming less energy, but I have to be cautious and not switch heat bed and hotend at once.

The major disadvantage of this thing is, that PSU have to be installed at the very beginning of ToyREP assembly. For latter upgrade you will have to disassemble almost the whole printer.

BoM

  1. Printed cover - 1 pc
  2. Main power supply cable -1 pc (for eg. 1,5m long PC power cable)
  3. Power switch -1 pc (rated 250V 1A, for mounting hole 13x19mm)
  4. DC cable - 250mm piece (Two lines, distinguishable)
  5. Heatshrink - 100mm dia 5mm.
  6. Woodscreew 3x13 - 1pc
  7. Countersunk screew M3x6-8 - 3pcs
  8. Hexnut M8 - 1pc (additional to printer BoM)
  9. Washer M8 - 1pc (additional to printer BoM)

Assembly

Pictures are for PSU1 version, but should be valid for PSU2 too.

Cover

Print the cover from enclosed file. Mine was made of ABS, 0.5mm noozle, 0.25mm thick layers. 2 outlines, 3 top and bottom layers, 30% hexagonal infill. Clean it and try to push M8 Rod through. Also try to install and remove the power switch from the cover.

Cable

If you are going to use PC power cable, just cut off the end with PC euro connector and keep the power socket plug. Cut off an other 150mm of cable for internal connections. Strip of the outer layer on the 150mm piece and keep just the blue and brown wires.
Remove insulation on the ends of the wires. One end should be a bit longer if you are going to turn it around the screws of PSU connectors.
Strip also the ends of the DC power cable that will lead from PSU to Ramps. This two line cable should have one cable with black and an other with red colour insulation.

Soldering

Attach separate brown cable to the switch and cover the naked joint with a piece of heatshrink. If you have switch witch light, You will also have to connect the separate blue piece to the second circuit. Put power cable through round hole near the opening for power switch from outside to inside. Than take the naked ends out through the hole for power switch. Place heatshrink on cables that are going to be attached to switch. Solder brown and eventually blue cable to the remaining connectors on the switch.

Installing Wires

Connect yellow-green cable to earthing screw of the PSU. Place brown cable on L screw and blue on N screw. Install also two line cable. Red to V+ and black to V-. Put the 12V power cable from inside out through bottom round hole in the cover. Place the rod through the cover and bend wires around it. You can use zip ties, to clean the mess a bit.

Testing

Before you will close the PSU and install it into the printer, test if everything is running, and PSU is secure. Measure the output voltage and if needed adjust it to 12V with trimmer.

Covering

Place the cover over the connectors of PSU and tighten it atleast from one side with 3x13 wood screw.

Installation

With M3x6 or M3x8 countersunk screws tighten the PSU to the PCB1 and PCB2 part of the printer. Place these holders on the two X axis threaded rods, with washers and nuts and build the whole rest of the printer around it :D.

Warning

Be very careful when installing PSU as threaded rods may damage insulation on wires! If possible cover internal part of the threaded rod with duck tape.

description.text:
This spool holder relies on a friction locking system to secure spools of filament to a wall. The spool holder system can hold spools with a spool diameter of 1.275" or larger, and 3.6" deep.

The stopping circle has a diameter of 2.5"

Depending on your print quality, the lock will be very tight! In my case it takes some effort to separate the two pieces, which reassures me the spool won't fall off the wall.

FilamentChallenge
Extruder 220 degrees celcius Platform 110 degrees celcius

I'm growing hops this year for brewing and wanted a way to let the vines climb without being 50' tall, so I came up with this design using three 10' pvc pipes and 50' of paracord.  Hops seem happy so far :)

• Print out one bracket and 3 caps for each tepee. I suggest a light color. The cap fits tightly over a 1" pvc pipe. The hole is 5mm dia, I didn't have enough 5mm bolts for it, so I wound up putting some cuttings of 1.75mm filament through and melting the ends.

  • Drill holes down the sides of the pvc pipe to thread paracord through.

  • Assemble. 50' of paracord was plenty but I had to keep moving the legs of the tepee in to make it reach the top.

  • I hammered stakes down into the ground and slipped the pvc over top of it to hold them down.

title: DIPPY BIRD STAND AND TRAY, A MOUNT FOR THE DRINKING BIRD TOY

description.text:
The dippy bird has been a long time bestselling scientific toy. Just keep the ‘beak’ wet and the ‘bird’ keeps dipping. This adult toy is available from Scientifics or on E-Bay, but it comes with just a flimsy stand and it is hard to find a water glass of just the right height. Then the glass must be refilled frequently.
This stand holds the bird at the right height and the bottle holds a weeks’ worth of water. A separate tray catches water leaks.

The stand took 7 hours to print on an Ultimaker, and used about $5 worth of material. The .stl file already includes support in 2 places that must be broken out with pliers. No other support was needed.
The bottle cap must be 1.375”(35mm) diameter. It may take some shopping to find a drink bottle with a cap the right size.
It took 4 heavy varnish coats to seal the plastic and keep the parts from leaking water.
A caution: although it may be called a ‘toy’, the ‘bird’ itself is made of breakable glass and the fluid inside is paint remover. Not a plaything for small children or pets.
To refill: unscrew the bottle and fill. Then turn the stand upside down and screw onto the bottle. Then quickly flip it all right-side-up.
Some hints on the bird: 1. The metal crossbar is easy to bend, must be kept very straight. 2. The metal crossbar can be slid up or down to find the point of best performance. 3. Soaking in vinegar will clean off mineral deposits.
Files attached include .stl, .stp, inch format; .ics [IronCAD inch format

author: PARTMAKER

description.text:
When I was building ToyREP 3D Printer, burned one stepper, so I took it apart. Maybe you will find it useful for some future project.

When it was disassembled I made also model of the plastic cap as it get broken very easily. You can use it as a replacement or to customize the colour but beware it was not tested yet.

This particular motor have gears:

9 teeth on motor shaft
32 to 11 on first axis
22 to 9 on second axis
27 to 8 on third axis
24 teeth on output shaft.

(32x22x27x24)/(9x11x9x8)=64

The other motor I got previously had:

(32x22x26x31)/(9x11x9x10)=63.68395

1. Choose if you want cap with open hole for wires or closed. Open hole will let you install the cap with connector. For closed hole you will have to cut off connector.
  2. Print it as fine as possible :D.
  3. Slide wires through the hole
  4. Put the cap on place.

author: Andiroid

description.text: (see Thing Name)

Used a 2D image as a background, outlined the letters using single, sub-divided planes for each letter; then just extruded all of them. As a final touch, made a minor extrusion and shrunk it inward to add some classy beveling.
This is my take on a wind spire. It is a combination of a spire "SP" and an invelox "OX". https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NJt14-oj4jU

The idea for the SPOX came from a project some of my peers did for one of their engineering class projects. They built a small scale wind turbine. But the one big problem is that it was too small to actually work outside. Then I was watching the news a few weeks after they finished the project and I saw that tornadoes were blowing whole buildings away and that's where I got the idea for the SPOX. When I saw that I knew how to make a wind spire more efficient. I knew of the invelox before but I never thought of combining them before now, The way the SPOX works is the air comes in through the top and is bend and sent into the housing where it forms a vortex. In theory this should make the SPOX more efficient than a traditional wind spire or an invelox. The SPOX as posted here is only a 1:20 scale model because I wanted to have it be 3D printable. I do have to give a big shout out to Electronix Plus 1's hub over at 3D hubs for printing this out for me at a great price and with great accuracy and quality. I think that 3D printing technology is so cool and I want to win this contest so that I can bring more of my ideas such as the SPOX to life. Thank you for viewing, I hope you liked it.

description.text:
To aid the hungry lungs, this small container provides storage and convenience for various types of product. The design is focused around the relationship between skating and surfing, mother nature and the industrial man made features which provide so many of us with an escape from the everyday grind.

100mm diameter, 30mm high. My friend Max Meira sent me the drawing, and I turned it 3D...

I printed the pool main piece sitting as it would normally. There is a fillet around the inside edge under the pool, so support material is mainly printed under the actual base of the pool. I used some angled pointy nose pliers to remove it, and then sanded the base a bit to fully smooth it off.

The wave piece needs to be printed on its side, with the wave running perpendicular to the printer bed, as shown in the gallery picture. This just makes the wave a lot smoother, and the print grain runs along the wave which almost creates a cool look to the wave.

author: evco

description.text:
Weird, strange, and bizarre keychain :) If you look closely, the umbilical cord is wrapped several times around the neck.... :/

I have printed out three of these, but unfortunately I'm having problems getting a good resolution on my da Vinci 1.0A printer.. Perhaps you can do better! If you print one, please comment and post a picture!

I have several printed fetal specimens over at https://www.etsy.com/shop/FetalReproductions?ref=hdr_shop_menu, including several other awesome fetal fridge magnets and baby reproductions, so check those out, and keep checking, I'm adding several prints a week both here and on etsy!

This keychain was made from a high resolution CT scan of a fixed medical specimen from the last century. It has been manipulated, resized, and modified as a keychain. Looks eerily like an alien baby, and really makes an odd conversation piece..

comments.text: Too creepy for me  LOL
comments.author: mb20music

author: siddhant3s

description.text:
We have so many questions about how to do multi material prints that we decided to create a test file for all of the RoVa3D owners out there to try out at home. We selected 5 materials (ABS,PLA,WOOD,HIPS, CARBON).

Click below for a video from Chris while he was trying out the print for the first time. (You will notice he changed it up a bit as he went along by changing the anchor material on the several attempts.)

https://youtu.be/aFOsbpkRy0I
Check out the RoVa3D on our website:
http://ordsolutions.com

Material:
Orange HIPS (From ORD, 235C, 0.5mm extra on tool change restart, Anchor Material)
Blue ABS (From ORD, 230C, 1.6mm extra)
Green PLA (From ORD, 210C, 1.6mm extra)
Wood Wood (From ORD, 215C, 4mm extra)
Black Nanotube Carbon (From 3Dxtech, 5.5mm extra)

Print settings: 

All nozzles 0.5mm  
300um layer height  
175% extra extrusion on first layer  
20mms first layer  
40mms other layers  
2 solid bottom  
5 solid tops  
3 perimeters  
20% infill  
5mm @ 50mm/s retraction  
-80C Ooze delta with High skirt 25loops

Bed setup: 130C temp Kapton (From ORD) Aussie Extreme hold hair spray purple bottle (light coating on the Kapton)

Notes from Chris: I found that the Wood and the Carbon were very droooooly...The HIPS was chosen for the base anchor material because every other material sticks to it and it shows no warping and a perfectly flat bottom. Also, the wood bottom layers broke off when removing the print so the HIPS prevented that. I had difficulty getting the HIPS to stick to the Kapton so I used a light coating of hair spray (applied while the bed is hot) and it stuck sooo well that I damaged V1 taking it off the bed! There is a bit of a bug in slic3r so I had to manually remove all the tool changes in the first layer of the skirt. I just opened the gcode file in notepad++ and removed tool changes T1 to T0 (5 tool changes) with their temperature changes also. As far as I know this is the first 5 material print ever done in the world on an FDM printer!WE

comments.text: Love to get one  of those 3D Printers
comments.author: RC64nut
